channel.title: Anyone practice freestyle soccer?
channel.description:
Freestyle soccer is really cool if you can perform combos, or even just juggle. I'm pretty much an expert at juggling, and I can do a couple tricks, including a neck stall(only after a couple times), and I can also do a spin. If you're good at freestyle soccer, feel free to post ;) Heres a couple definitions of a few tricks.
"Spin" (Spin) is a pretty easy trick when you get used to it. You kick the ball into the air, maybe 7 feet or so, spin, and then when the ball comes down you stall or juggle.
"Around the World" (ATW) is also popular; in this move, the player plays the ball off of one foot, and that foot then circles up and over the ball before before returning underneath to play the ball again.
"Stall" moves involve catching the ball in a stationary position. Many freestylers are able to catch the ball on their foreheads, the backs of their necks, or wedged between their heel and the back of their thigh.
"Combos" are where one trick is connected to another without juggling the ball. For example a combo could be: ATW - ATW - Hop the World (HTW) - Touzani Around the World (TATW) - HTW - Mitchy Around the World (MATW).

Just because I’m from the U.S. doesn’t mean that I like it. I find it retarded that the football team at my school (Who came in last place in the worst league) gets a huge locker room, and all the nice equipment, when my school’s soccer team has been state champions more times than any highschool in California, and is far more superior (and tough for that matter) than our pussy Football players.[/quote]

And American football can carry around 46 players on their team at a time, whereas Soccer (European football) can only carry a max of 18, and each sport only allows 11 on the field at a time. item.title: Anyone practice freestyle soccer?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

This isn’t really ‘freestyle soccer’ as you like to define it. But I guess you can call is whatever you want. I would say this is just juggling with style.

And I do most of these in games, but only when possible. Stalling helps alot, because lets say somebody lobs a ball to you and you want to control it. You slow it down so by the time it reaches the ground, it has stopped in front of you, allowing for a shot.

As for a ‘spin’, I don’t think 7 feet is necessary. What I do when somebody is on my back, is give it a kick over my shoulder or to one side, spin around the guy, then bring it back into my possession.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone practice freestyle soccer?
item.dc:creator: @ninjasod ninjasod
item.description:
@ninjasod wrote:

Freestyle soccer is really cool if you can perform combos, or even just juggle. I’m pretty much an expert at juggling, and I can do a couple tricks, including a neck stall(only after a couple times), and I can also do a spin. If you’re good at freestyle soccer, feel free to post
Heres a couple definitions of a few tricks.

“Spin” (Spin) is a pretty easy trick when you get used to it. You kick the ball into the air, maybe 7 feet or so, spin, and then when the ball comes down you stall or juggle.

“Around the World” (ATW) is also popular; in this move, the player plays the ball off of one foot, and that foot then circles up and over the ball before before returning underneath to play the ball again.

“Stall” moves involve catching the ball in a stationary position. Many freestylers are able to catch the ball on their foreheads, the backs of their necks, or wedged between their heel and the back of their thigh.

“Combos” are where one trick is connected to another without juggling the ball. For example a combo could be:
ATW - ATW - Hop the World (HTW) - Touzani Around the World (TATW) - HTW - Mitchy Around the World (MATW).

Read full topic
